answers.q: what is sodium silicate used for
answers.a: In foods, E550 sodium silicate is used mainly as an anti-caking/flow agent in dry powders; outside food it serves as a binder/adhesive and deflocculant in detergents, paper, cement, and ceramics.
At the low levels used in foods it isn’t considered toxic by major regulators, but concentrated solutions are strongly alkaline and can irritate or burn skin, eyes, and the GI tract.

answers.q: how to use sodium silicate in pottery
answers.a: Use it as a deflocculant by adding very small amounts (often with a little soda ash) to clay slip until the desired specific gravity/viscosity is reached; it can also be brushed on and the surface stretched to create crackle textures—wear gloves and avoid over‑addition.

answers.q: is sodium silicate safe for skin
answers.a: Undiluted or moderately concentrated sodium silicate is not skin‑safe because it’s caustic; only very dilute formulations (as in some cosmetics) are used on skin, and even then may cause irritation in sensitive individuals.
